intro: Gilia cephaloidea, commonly known as the Sierra gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in open, rocky habitats and is often found in mountainous regions. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and its flowers are clustered in terminal spikes. Gilia cephaloidea is an important plant for pollinators and is adapted to thrive in arid environments.
